comments_content.body:
Confirmed because 

this fails
```
plot(D, R="-1/3/-1/3", J="x2c", B=0, Z=[1,4], G="+z", C=C)
```
but saving the ``[1,4]`` in a file then this works
```
plot(D, R="-1/3/-1/3", J="x2c", B=0, Z="z.dat", G="+z", C=C)
```

Trying to make sense of this section (which is where the KEY `ZD(= `is going.  The _gmtapi_extract_argument_ call does that.  It finds the = with nothing after it and all it does is to set implicit, meaning we expect an implicit input file.

The gmt_access returns 0 if given a memory file so the Z.file should be strdup'ed here.  What are you passing in the command?

The key is correct and no need for anyone to have changed that since you are the only one with test cases for this.  Are you setting and passing a memory file via -Z? If so then opt->arg cannot be not set (GMT does not remove things).

> What are you passing in the command?

I showed above, ``Z=[1,4]``

If you click the example you see that it has worked before.
yes, but you are not passing [1,4] to Call_Module.  You are creating a virtual data set and passing its name, no?
I am asking since I do not understand if you passed -Z@GMTAPI-########### why opt->arg can be empty.
I'm doing the exact the same thing as with all the other options that pass memory data. The functions are generic, no special treatment for this -Z option.

See, ``opt->arg`` is empty.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/537321/146704735-062ee389-cd6f-4597-a568-f9e25e8f6867.png)

OK, I guess I need to fire up Julia and see if I can still do Xcode (macOS and Xcode update since last time).  My suspicion has to do with some checks for remote global grids which start with `@` and then we have the `@GMTAPI` start which perhaps I forgot to exempt...
If you are already in the debug, follow it into the gmt_init_module and see where the opt->arg gets eaten.
Can't debug Julia. Takes an eternity to step.
OK, but you are able set a verbose flag to print out the cmd string for Call_Module, no?

But there is no problem there. Data is well transmitted by the generic code. You keep doubting this.

Sometimes the program crash and following one of those crashes I found that the Z values are in fact inside the lib. The psxy.c line 2366
```
for (tbl = 0; tbl < D->n_tables; tbl++) {
```
has ``n_tables`` = 2 and the second table holds the column vector with the Z values. Then latter down and because ``polygon`` = true it crashes when it calls ``gmtplot_at_pole()`` because there is no ``*lat``.

So the Z data was indeed read but landed on the wrong place.

![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/537321/146773547-9dba5081-b749-454b-ab5b-c703cb888e0b.PNG)

One-liner that shows the problem
```
plot(mat2ds(cat([0. 0; 0 1; 1 1; 1 0.3; 0 0], [1 1; 1 2; 2 2; 2 1; 1 1], dims=3)), R="-1/3/-1/3", J="x2c", B=0, Z=[1.2 0;4 0], G="+z", C=makecpt(C=:hot, T="0/5"))
```
And if I change the KEY from ``ZD(=`` to ``ZD(`` then it works fine again.
Since -Z has no modifiers I wonder if the = is a relic of a previous version of -Z.  I cannot see why it would need anything special either.
Please make a PR for the change to the KEY.  I need to add some comments somewhere to explain this black magic.

That KEY change was part of a larger commit (3/7/2020) that changed other likewise KEYs

* Correct keys settings for files to be read via options (#2857)

* Correct keys settings for files to be read via options



From: Paul Wessel ***@***.***>
Sent: Monday, December 20, 2021 6:33 PM
To: GenericMappingTools/gmt ***@***.***>
Cc: Joaquim Manuel Freire Luís ***@***.***>; Author ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [GenericMappingTools/gmt] plot -Z broken in Julia (Issue #6133)


Please make a PR for the change to the KEY. I need to add some comments somewhere to explain this black magic.

—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/issues/6133#issuecomment-998173320>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAEDF2LYDVWZNDGRJQABUWTUR5ZF3ANCNFSM5KMRLWAA>.
Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS<https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id1477376905?ct=notification-email&mt=8&pt=524675> or Android<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.github.android&referrer=utm_campaign%3Dnotification-email%26utm_medium%3Demail%26utm_source%3Dgithub>.
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.******@***.***>>

Maybe be I need to document this better first before we change.  It is not
at all clear to me now what the = and + and trailing integers really do.
It was clear when I coded it but that braincell died.

> @GMTAPI-

Just an off-topic question. Are these remote files that are download?
No. Those are internal names of the virtual files.

> No. Those are internal names of the virtual files.

Mm ok. I remember that once I have an error. I was on a PC without internet and I got an error that said I couldn't get that filed. It worked when I connect the PC to internet. I must said that I am not complete sure. How can I test this?

Not sure if you can - but should be completely unrelated.  The @GMTAPI-##### are fake filenames that GMT uses to pass memory objects between modules.  It has nothing to do with the remote file mechanism.  For example, when you use grdimage -I+d to auto-generate a shading grid from the input topo, grdimage will set up a call to grdgradient to do that work and it returns a grid via these virtual file names.

> > No. Those are internal names of the virtual files.
> 
> Mm ok. I remember that once I have an error. I was on a PC without internet and I got an error that said I couldn't get that filed. It worked when I connect the PC to internet. I must said that I am not complete sure. How can I test this?

There was a bug that internal names `@GMTAPI-xxx` were incorrectly considered as remote files. The bug affected GMT 6.1.0 (and maybe also GMT 6.0.0) but was fixed in GMT >=6.1.1 by PR https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/pull/3745.
Closing based on https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/pull/6134

title: plot -Z broken in Julia
